body.p: Which type of homeostasis feedback is involved in these two examples?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The initiation event and result would have to be the same because this would cause more of the same stimulus.
Correct. The result is opposite, which stops the initial stimulus and release of the hormone.

part.hint: Compare the initiation event and the result from stimulating the different target organs. Notice the two examples have opposite initiation events and effects, but each brings the level back within homeostatic range.

question.body: Which cells of the thyroid gland are involved in this plasma calcium ion homeostasis?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Be careful not to confuse these cells of a different gland because it also includes the prefix “para”.
Correct. These C cells are located between the follicles of the thyroid gland.
Incorrect. These cells are in-between the tubules where sperm formation occurs in testes.
Incorrect. These cells secrete a hormone-like chemical that only affects near cells.

part.hint: These are not the epithelial cells forming the follicle around the colloid for T3 & T4 production inside the thyroid gland.

question.body: Which cells of the parathyroid gland are involved in this plasma calcium ion homeostasis?

response.feedback: Incorrect. These are located between the follicles of the thyroid gland and produce calcitonin.
Incorrect. These are located in the pancreas and produce insulin.
Correct. These cells produce PTH in response to falling plasma calcium levels.
Incorrect. The function of these cells in the parathyroid gland is not fully understood, but they don’t produce PTH.

part.hint: This is the “primary” but not only type of cell found in this endocrine gland.

question.body: Which of the following cells would not have receptors for calcitonin and PTH?

multiple_choice.choice: kidney cells of the nephron tubule

response.feedback: Incorrect. Calcitonin-receptor complex inhibits these cells from reabsorbing calcium from the filtrate so it is excreted in urine, while PTH-receptor complex stimulates these cells to reabsorb calcium increasing blood calcium levels.
Correct. Neither hormone has any effect on the gastric digestion, although food is one source of calcium in the blood.
Incorrect. Calcitonin-receptor complex prevents them from dissolving the bone matrix, while PTH-receptor complex stimulates matrix resportion releasing calcium into blood.
Incorrect. Calcitonin-receptor complex inhibits calcium absorption, while PTH-receptor complex works with vitamin D to increase calcium absorption from food into blood.

part.hint: The hormones will only cause the resulting metabolic change in cells with specific receptor for that hormone. The cell will have receptors for both hormones, so the opposite responses will be determined by which hormone is being secreted and binding to the receptor at that time.

question.body: While the indirect effect of both calcitonin and PTH on osteoblasts is still being studied, what would be the expected effect of each hormone?

part.hint: Similar to the effect on osteoclasts, their effects would be opposite, one stimulating and other inhibiting; but the end result of the specific hormone would stay the same.
part.explanation: Calcitonin would stimulate osteoblast activity to deposit more bone matrix, removing it from the blood. PTH would inhibit osteoblasts so they don’t remove the blood calcium being conserved by the kidney and absorbed by the intestine.
